Dialogue: Shit.

Dialogue: Mien Prisoner!

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Hey, Siegfreid and Roy. What are you waiting for? Kill me.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Come on you pussies. Let's get this over with.

Speaker: german officer
Dialogue: You will write your mother. Tell her how you will die now.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Genuine Third Reich issue, no less. Nice work.

Speaker: german officer
Dialogue: You will write. How you die alone.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: My mother and I don't have that kind of relationship.

Speaker: german officer
Dialogue: Write.

Speaker: german officer
Dialogue: Enough. Now you will beg for your life.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: What don't you understand?

Speaker: infantryman
Dialogue: The protocol says we should -

Speaker: german officer
Dialogue: I am the fucking protocol.  Beg!

Speaker: german officer
Dialogue: Beg - for - your - life!

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: You got to be kidding me.

Speaker: german officer
Dialogue: Silence. Now I have a little fun.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Now that's against the rules.

Speaker: german officer
Dialogue: There are no rules in war.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: You've never killed anyone before, have you?

Speaker: german officer
Dialogue: I shower in the blood of my victims --

Speaker: gi
Dialogue: No wonder you smell so bad.

Speaker: german officer
Dialogue: Don't shoot, please.

Speaker: gi
Dialogue: Will you look at the manners on this guy?  Remember to thank me when I kill you.

Speaker: german officer
Dialogue: No, really, not in the neck -

Speaker: gi
Dialogue: You all right?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Yeah. My elaborate death scene wasn't going anywhere anyway.

Speaker: gi
Dialogue: You want me to give you a minute?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: That's okay. They'll get me eventually. If you can't get killed in a war, when can you?

Speaker: gi
Dialogue: That's right. Look on the bright side.

Speaker: gi
Dialogue: Bart. Bart Bowland.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Kelly. Kelly Ernswiler.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Kelly?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Bart?

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: I mean - that's Irish, right?

Speaker: german officer
Dialogue: Why the fuck did you have to shoot that cap so close to my neck? You gave me a powder burn.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Listen you wienerschnitzel. You should talk. You slapped me. I'm not your bitch.

Speaker: german officer
Dialogue: Well, what was that whole creepy death wish thing about?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Well it didn't work, now did it?

Speaker: german officer
Dialogue: Sometimes I get so caught up in the moment.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: And what was that ridiculous shit about making me write to my mother?

Speaker: german officer
Dialogue: Inspired, wasn't it?

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Dude, you made him write to his mother? Who are you, Dr. Phil?

Speaker: infantryman
Dialogue: Can we get up now?

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Might as well. There's only an hour left anyway.

Speaker: german officer
Dialogue: Admit it. You were scared.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Right.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: That Willys yours?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Yup. Just got her. Three summers packing out at Shop Rite.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: My bad. Thanks though.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: See you.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Well, come on.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: I couldn't resist.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Real funny, Ernswiler. You might still get your chance to die today.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Character building? Those crazy guys from Ann Arbor tied them to a dock.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: That's what you get for invading Wisconsin.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: D-Day at Kenosha was nothing. At Guadalcanal Chillicothe there was a guy who actually injected himself with malaria.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: That's crazy.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Where do you live, anyway?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Shaker Heights.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: That explains the death wish. Me too. What street?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Penn Place.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Hmm, don't know it.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: It's not technically in Shaker Heights - but I go to Shaker Heights High.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Langely Prep.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Sorry to hear that.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Well, I got kicked out of Shaker Heights High because my birdhouse came unglued in honors woodshop.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Of course. I would have gone to Langely myself only my polo pony had the fits.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: No matter.  We're all soldiers here.

Speaker: crowd
Dialogue: That's right./Here, here./ Whooping, cheers, etc.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: You should come over some time. Service our lawnmower.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: I would, but then I might soil my croquet whites. You understand.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: How bourgeois. Cheerio then.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Sleep tight Hot Lips.

Speaker: abe
Dialogue: Sergeant Keller! How was the war? Did we win?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Let me guess. Happy Meals for the wavy gravy wellness center?

Speaker: abe
Dialogue: As usual, your cynicism is refreshing.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: As usual, your cheerful optimism makes me ill.

Speaker: abe
Dialogue: You should get that checked.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Sure thing, doc. Say hello to Leif Garrett for me.

Speaker: mao
Dialogue: Son of Eve. You are very dirty.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: A rough charge. You know.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Now Nana, the gold has to be feathery, not gloppy - see?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Now you try.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: She loves the gold. Always overuses it. And usually her touch is so light.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: You know why we never have anything to eat in this house?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Mao, what did we say about the eyes?

Speaker: mao
Dialogue: More - empathy?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: That's right. And didn't I tell you to put in more cacti?

Speaker: mao
Dialogue: No, no more cacti. Too busy. Simplicity is best.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Oh boy. I'm not having this battle with you again.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Because your husband takes food from his own family to feed every loser druggie in Cleveland.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Well, you can always chip in here. We're ordering pizza later.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: No. Some people have to work later.  Will you drop something off at the dry cleaners for me tomorrow?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Sweetie, you know what we said about paying for the war things. Nothing's changed.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: It's the only thing I ever ask you for --

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Don't be dramatic.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: But it's important to me.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: You're just going to have to find a way to pay for it yourself then, I guess.  No - not that way - the sky should be stormier. Angry clouds.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Why do I bother?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: More brown, less blue.

Speaker: abe
Dialogue: Now Keller, who needs that sandwich more - you or the daughter of a crack addict trying to make a new life?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: How about the son of a heroin addict trying to get ready for work?

Speaker: abe
Dialogue: That went well.

Speaker: sarah
Dialogue: So how'd your battle go today? I still don't understand how you could reenact the Battle of the Bulge in seventy-two degree weather.  Didn't all those guys freeze to death?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Well, a Port-a-John fell over on a couple of guys.

Speaker: sarah
Dialogue: That's gross.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: War is hell.

Speaker: sarah
Dialogue: Then why do you do it?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: You're never more alive then when facing simulated death.

Speaker: sarah
Dialogue: Really? Maybe I should try it.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: You are William J. Stone of the 1st Airborne, pinned down in Noville. The Germans have the high ground and they're shelling your position heavily.  You're holed up in a stone barn. Sustaining heavy casualties. Running low on ammo. The cries of wounded men fill the air like the cries of hungry babies.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Your commanding officer gets hit in the face, dies. At 1 p.m. you lose radio contact with headquarters. If you withdraw, the Germans will flank the entire Allied forces arrayed along Bastogne and break the front. What do you do? What do you do?

Speaker: sarah
Dialogue: Stop it!

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Battle of Bulge, the Southern

Speaker: sarah
Dialogue: Sorry I asked.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Hey. Want a snack? We got a whole shipment in of busted Oreo's.

Speaker: sarah
Dialogue: I'll accidentally drop a couple pints of milk and meet you over there.

Speaker: sarah
Dialogue: The frozen food woman came in with her kids. They must eat out of those little cardboard trays every night. One of the kids looked like cardboard.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Do you know we stock more flavors of cat food than we do baby food?

Speaker: sarah
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Sixteen flavors of baby food including the toddler meals-in-ajar, thirty- one flavors of cat food.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Next time you should tell that woman to buy her kid some cat food.

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: Is this store open? I've been waiting up front. If the store's closed, it shouldn't have a sign that says twenty- four hours.

Speaker: sarah
Dialogue: Sorry about that.

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: I have a lot of coupons and I don't want to be here when they expire.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Charge her double for everything.

Speaker: lance
Dialogue: What the fuck are you looking at, GI Jane?

Speaker: lance
Dialogue: No really, what makes you think you can look at me?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: I honestly didn't know it was you. I thought it was a free preview of the Spice Channel.

Speaker: lance
Dialogue: That's pretty funny. You got dental insurance?

Speaker: bridget
Dialogue: Stop it.

Speaker: lance
Dialogue: What? What?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Come on. Isn't this analysis a tad simplistic? I mean, maybe for a second grade history class, sure - but to insist on still characterizing the Civil War as some moral struggle? The soldiers were drafted - the only ones who had to fight were the ones who couldn't afford to pay their way out.  Why don't you talk about the Draft Riots? Where are your slides for that?

Speaker: holmstead
Dialogue: What gives you the idea that you can or ought to question the curriculum?

Speaker: holmstead
Dialogue: Or question your teacher?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: I know. I mean, who ever heard of a classroom dialog? Not Socrates.

Speaker: holmstead
Dialogue: Kelly, you're a very bright boy. But you're making some serious mistakes.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: I don't need to. Everyone else makes them for me.

Speaker: holmstead
Dialogue: This anger must be masking a lot of hurt.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: I was wondering what the tissues were for.

Speaker: holmstead
Dialogue: I see you're not going to college next year. What are your plans?

Speaker: holmstead
Dialogue: How do I get through to you?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Advertisers use status and sex to appeal to my demographic.

Speaker: holmstead
Dialogue: I think we can come up with a punishment which might actually be more of an opportunity for you to realize your true potential.

Speaker: lance
Dialogue: You upset Bridget.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Give me a break.

Speaker: lance
Dialogue: You need to apologize.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: What are you going to do, make out with me?

Speaker: lance
Dialogue: Why are you fucking with me? You little fucker. Want to play, fuckface?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: You just used fuck as a verb, noun, and adjective. Impressive.

Speaker: lance
Dialogue: Let's see what Beetle Bailey's got in his knapsack.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Rim job.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Kelly. Hey.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: You work here?

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Just a couple days a month, to get a heads-up on the latest stuff. What are you doing?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Looking for a backpack.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Is that all? Don't bother. I have a couple extras at home. I could give you one if you want.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Sure, I guess.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Very impressive.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: My dad's real into hoarding.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: What's this?

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Grant's field flask.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Wow. Your dad should meet my history teacher. He sent me to the principal's office today for questioning his G- rated interpretation of the Civil War.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Forget him.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: I would, but now the principal's making me give a speech on the Civil War at an assembly.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: What is he, some kind of sadist?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: She thinks she's doing me a favor.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Jesus, she must think you're really screwed up. Are you?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Depends on who you ask. Everyone's got an opinion.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Take this. That'll shut them up.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Stonewall Jackson's.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Yeah right.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Can you imagine that? Losing your leg and getting back up on your horse? Unbelievable. What balls.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: He's got so much crap crammed in here he doesn't even notice when it's missing. I saw a backpack in here somewhere.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: I thought he had a couple.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: I'd feel weird taking one out of the tomb of Tutenkamen anyway.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Trust me, you shouldn't.  Where'd your old one go?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: I lost it.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: How?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Someone took it.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: You let someone take it?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: I didn't let him. I told off some idiot --

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Sounds like your mouth gets you into trouble a lot.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: I'm telling you, it's not me, it's the world.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Tabby, this is Kelly.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: Don't give him any money, whatever you do.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Shut up.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: All these little old ladies are looking for him in Arizona. He took their retirement money and bought defective bazookas with it.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Very funny. We're paying attention to you, are you happy now?

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: Finally, my life is complete. Fait accompli.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Minnie's making sloppy joes. Want one?

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: Sloppy joe? Sloppy no.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: I have to go take a shower. Will you call me when Miner gets here?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Who's Miner?

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: The fianc.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Listen, I'm going to the flea market on Saturday. I have a line on a couple dealers. You could get a backpack there.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Oh yeah? Flea market, land of bargains.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Especially if you know who to talk to.

Speaker: lance
Dialogue: Hey fuckface. Like my new hat? I just joined the Boy Scouts.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: If you stay in it long enough, maybe you'll get your fudgepacker badge.

Speaker: lance
Dialogue: You're a regular Howie Mandel.

Speaker: bridget
Dialogue: Lance!

Speaker: lance
Dialogue: Okay babe.  One day you and me will be alone. And won't that be nice?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Too bad my mom won't let me date yet.

Speaker: sarah
Dialogue: Why do you mess with him?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: You're right. I should give him a break.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Oh, Kelly, you're home. Good. I need you to go to the art supply store for me.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Get Abe to do it.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: He was going to but he had to go lead a meeting at Care House.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: What a surprise.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: I'll make it up to you.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Where have I heard that before?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: When are you going to give me a break?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Let me think - maybe when I finally forget every single word of The Little Mermaid soundtrack I'd listen to in the car waiting for him to score. No, probably when I don't prepare myself before I go into the bathroom, expecting to find him passed out on the floor.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Actually, you know what? I know I'll be able to put it all behind me when I go away to college.  Only, I can't go because someone spent my college fund on Mexican Black Tar. So looks like I'll have to try to forget at Shop Rite, where I'll be working for the rest of my life.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: You're right. You have every reason to crawl into the corner and give up. But please just get me some paints first.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: What do you need?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: We need burnt sienna, cadmium red, and midnight blue. Two tubes of blue.  What happened to your face?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Forget it.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: They're having a sale on glitter.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: Oh, hello. What happened to you?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Tennis injury.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: You paint?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Well, you see... That's a difficult question.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: How so?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: I don't really feel comfortable calling anything done since the Renaissance "painting." We might have a more experimental interaction with the picture plane, but our skills have suffered from it.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: You're working with acrylic. Why? Oil's much - richer.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: Oh you're not one of those oil snobs are you?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Of course not.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: It's just - isn't acrylic a bit - jejune?

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: Jejune? You're jejune. How old are you anyway?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Older than my years.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: And you paint?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Well, you know, my mother's kind of an artist, so -

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: That explains it.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: That explains nothing. Doesn't anyone believe in innate knowledge anymore? Michelangelo was fifteen when he painted the Infanta.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: Infantas are Spanish. Michelangelo was Italian.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Exactly. One world, one people. Just like Jesse Jackson envisioned.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: Well - Kelly. Nice talking to you.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: What the hell did you just say?

Speaker: skinny guy
Dialogue: That there's actual sand from Iwo Jima.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Or your sister's sandbox.

Speaker: skinny guy
Dialogue: Well, it don't come with no certificate of authenticity.  I could write one up for you, I suppose. Get it notarized.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: No, that's quite all right. Actually, I'm in the market for medals.

Speaker: skinny guy
Dialogue: Sure. I got a couple purple hearts. A Silver Star. DSC. Can't sell them to you though. They were gramp's.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Are you sure?

Speaker: skinny
Dialogue: They have a lot of sentimental value -

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Yeah. How much?

Speaker: skinny guy
Dialogue: A lot.

Speaker: skinny guy
Dialogue: What's this?

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: General Ulysses S. Grant's field flask, my friend.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Throw in one of those backpacks and we'll call it even.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Buying and selling US service medals is illegal.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Exactly. That's why the resale value is so high.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Is that what they teach you at Langely?

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Don't be so nave. We all have our skeletons. Some of them just pay more than others.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: And I'm not even going to ask about the flask.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Don't ask, don't tell. The army gets everything right, don't they?

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: You boys look like Goldwater fans.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: I've never been accused of that before.

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: Well jeez, you don't have to be insulted.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Anything military?

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: Fish around in that cigar box.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: What do you want for the box?

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: Twenty dollars.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Fifteen.

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: Don't be so hasty.  I got a few Geraldine Ferraro pins I'm looking to unload.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Goldwater fan. I think that's some kind of insult.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Not at Dartmouth. Where are you going to go to school?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: I'm not.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Ah, you have that luxury.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: You don't?

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: I didn't have much say in the matter. Everything has been decided for me since birth. I'm not whining about it. Play the hand you're dealt, right?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Easy for you to say. You got a royal flush.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Are you crazy? My life sucks. Everyone's always telling me what to do. You can't fight it. Go with the flow.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: What about Tabby?

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: She got to go where she wanted. Sarah Lawrence. Six years. She's almost done with grad school. Yale.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: I didn't think people actually went to Yale.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: I don't know. I mean, she drives off in her car in September. For all we know, she could just pull her car over in Albany and sleep there until May.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: It was a joke. Joke?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Oh. Is that what one of those sounds like? Somehow, I always imagined they would be funnier.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Sarah Lawrence? Isn't that for lesbians?

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: What happened to your face?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Remember the backpack incident?

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Same guy?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: The one with mad cow-diseased hamburger meat for brains? That would be the one.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: What are you going to do about it?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: I'm not going to lower myself to his level.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Of course not. But there are alternatives

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Alternatives?

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Haven't you ever heard of the 193rd Special Operations Wing?

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Well do you want to get this guy or what?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: All right. Let's get the fuck out of here, then.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: I have some things to show you.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Once we've gathered the intelligence, the plan will reveal itself.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: We don't plan first?

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: No, it limits our scope - what's the objective?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Humiliation. Rage. Despair.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Easy enough. 'Nam's probably our go- to war for that sort of thing. I have the declassified briefs from the Phoenix Project around here somewhere.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: Hey. I have some stretcher bars out in the car. Can somebody help me bring them in?

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Of course we'll drop what we're doing because what you're doing must be more important.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Sure. I mean, I'll help.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: I'll find those reports.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Gold. The color of the sun.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: That's the Cleveland waterfront.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: As the viewer, I get to decide what it is, I'm afraid. And it doesn't look a thing like it.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: It's the light. I was playing with diffusion.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Well make sure you put it away when you're done with it.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: Very funny, wiseass.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: It must be nice to have a place like this to get away to.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: It is.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: What about Farmer?

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: Farmer?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: The boyfriend.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: Miner? What about him?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Is he an artist, too?

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: No. Definitely not. Thank god.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: You said your mom was a painter?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: She was, well - is I guess.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: She used to be. But then my dad - wasn't working anymore so she turned it into a business. She has a family of Chinese immigrants in the garage making them for her.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: Like Andy Warhol's Factory.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: More like Andy Warhol's tool shed. It was nice before, though. My playpen used to be in her studio.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: Wow. So you really grew up with it. What does, did, your dad do?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: He's a VH-1 documentary without the music.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: "Tragedy struck?"

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: "And then, things took a turn for the worse."

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: Well, just wait. Those burnout types always have a triumphant comeback tour.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: I already changed the channel.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Christ Kelly, I let you go out on a little supply line assist and you're gone for days. Come on.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: Have fun, boys.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: If only it were fun. War's deadly serious, ma'am.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: And I used to think you were the only crazy one.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Enough with the mind pollution, Hanoi Hannah.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: I'm worried about you playing with diffusion unsupervised.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: Are you?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Yes. I might have to come by and show you the proper safety procedures. Some time in the presence of an art prodigy would do you good.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: I don't think I have room for a playpen in here.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Ouch.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: So, you have a thing for my sister?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: What? No, no.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Everybody does.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: We just have a few things in common.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Oh really, like what?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: I can't tell you. It's my feminine side.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: You don't wear women's clothes when you're alone, do you?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Dad.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Dad?

Speaker: addict
Dialogue: Wha?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Sorry.

Speaker: abe
Dialogue: Keller. There's a meteor shower.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: A funny thing just happened. A little trip down memory lane. I thought you were on our couch, dead.

Speaker: abe
Dialogue: Oh, you mean Emmett? They didn't have an empty bed for him at Care House.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Well that's one of your more brilliant ideas.  Have you thought about the fact that it might be dangerous? That he might steal something, or go into cardiac arrest? Drink all our cooking wine? Which he seems to have done.

Speaker: abe
Dialogue: He just needs a place to sleep for the night.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: You're right. Besides, having him here makes it feel like home.

Speaker: abe
Dialogue: I've been straight for four years, almost five. A third of your life.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Big whoop. I've been straight the whole time.

Speaker: abe
Dialogue: I hate to tell you this, but I'm not your problem anymore.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: No. That's the one thing I get to decide.

Speaker: abe
Dialogue: Let me know. I can wait.

Speaker: abe
Dialogue: Keller, there's a meteor shower.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: I have the target in sight.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: I think he's leaving.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Let me see. Don't be a farb, give them up.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: The coast is clear.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Let me prepare to deploy.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Is this going to work?

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: We've planned for every contingency using the tried and true techniques of the last great world power.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Save it for the press conference.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Stay low. On my signal.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: We're the good guys. If you scream, the bad guys are going to come and burn down your house. Okay? So stay here and be quiet.

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: My dad has a gun.

Speaker: neighbor
Dialogue: Can I help you, young man?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: I was just inspecting your lawn.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Have you thought about Astroturf? It takes a lot less water to keep green. I mean, no water, technically.

Speaker: neighbor
Dialogue: I'm not interested.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Oh. I see. Okay then.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Oh, shit.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Oh, shit.

Speaker: lance
Dialogue: Smile worker bee. I'll be your boss some day.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: What an asshole. His mom gave me cookies, though.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Did you get it done?

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Don't ask stupid questions. Let's go home and listen.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: It was a five-watt FM bug, so we should be in range -

Speaker: lance's mom
Dialogue: So then I told her, "Harriet, with potato salad like that it's no wonder Ray-Ray's cheating on you."

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: You didn't.

Speaker: lance's mom
Dialogue: You're right. But I was thinking it. Instead I just told her to add more vinegar next time, and -

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: I don't think we can use any of this.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Be patient. It's voice activated, so we'll get everything. Trust me. It's going to be great.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: All right, then.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: We reconnoiter tomorrow at nineteen hundred hours.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: -- And if we don't sell them there, we'll set up on the corner of Stevens and Lane, by the gas station. That's a good location.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Are you listening to me?

Speaker: abe
Dialogue: Did you make this with more chili pepper than usual?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: The same as always.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Kelly. Want dinner?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: I ate.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: One day, we're all going to be happy.

Speaker: abe
Dialogue: That sounds nice.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: It's really too perfect, actually.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: What? What?

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: I can't describe. Just hit play. It's all cued up.

Speaker: bridget
Dialogue: I told you, that makes me nervous. Me no likey.

Speaker: lance
Dialogue: But baby, my birthday's coming up.

Speaker: bridget
Dialogue: Still. That's not a good enough reason.

Speaker: lance
Dialogue: Come on. A little action. A little prime time action.

Speaker: bridget
Dialogue: But people might see us.

Speaker: lance
Dialogue: That's the point. That's what makes it sexxxy. Dangerous.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Dangerous.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Exactly.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Let's draw up the plans.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: I have a few notes jotted down.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Oh Jesus, I'm so sorry -

Speaker: bridget
Dialogue: Oh, it's okay -

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: She dots her I's with hearts. And her L's are loopier. The L is very important.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: I'm working on it.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: I feel kind of bad for her. She's a nice girl.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Sometimes collateral damage can't be avoided.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Stop it.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: How does that look?

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Pretty good. I think we're ready to manufacture a document.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Begin. "Hey Daddy. It's your birthday and you've been a very bad boy. But so has the baby. Both baby and Daddy have to get punished, only this time -

Speaker: lance
Dialogue: - baby makes the rules. Await further instructions at school tomorrow --

Speaker: lance
Dialogue: -- Baby will be waiting where Daddy least expects her. Love, Bridgie." Yes!

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Do you have everything?

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: We can't afford any errors.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: You don't need to tell me. It's my ass on the line.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: I wish I could be there to see it.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: You'll get the de-brief.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: It's a day that will live in infamy.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: You couldn't do any better than that?

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: I don't hear you coming up with anything.

Speaker: bridget
Dialogue: What's gotten into you?

Speaker: lance
Dialogue: Nothing, you bad girl.

Speaker: bridget
Dialogue: Did you drink a bottle of Robitussin before school again?

Speaker: lance
Dialogue: See you soon, my naughty baby.

Speaker: lance
Dialogue: It's my birthday! I'm going to get a present.

Speaker: lance
Dialogue: Damn it, fuckface. What're you smiling about? You wish you were me.

Speaker: lance
Dialogue: Mr. Palmer? May I be excused?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Eine maus findet den kase.

Speaker: lance
Dialogue: Daddy's here for the Easter egg hunt.

Speaker: lance
Dialogue: Ooh, push my buttons.

Speaker: lance
Dialogue: Oh yeah. Oh yeah. You little minx.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Yes, I need to get a message to Bridget Shumann. This is MENSA.

Speaker: bridget
Dialogue: But I just got this note last period.

Speaker: secretary
Dialogue: Well I don't have anything here for you - let me look again. Oh yes, the MENSA called.

Speaker: bridget
Dialogue: Cool. They want me to be an honorary member.  Is that like a sorority or something?

Speaker: lance
Dialogue: Bridgie? Come on, daddy's sick. He needs his medicine.

Speaker: lance
Dialogue: I brought our friend along. He's happy to see you.

Speaker: lance
Dialogue: What the fuck are you all looking at?

Speaker: student 1
Dialogue: Look, he's got a hard on.

Speaker: student 2
Dialogue: Eeeeew.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: You're kidding me.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Yup. There it was. The whole school saw it. Wasn't too impressive either.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: To Operation Mincemeat.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: To the 193rd.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: How does it feel to give better than you get?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Good. Real good.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: You want some more?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Don't mind if I do.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: That's my boy.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: You know what this is?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Eighteen volts of pure freedom.

Speaker: sarah
Dialogue: Sounds dangerous.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Oh, it is. Unless you know how to handle it.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: You ever seen the freshly waxed floor in the produce section glistening under full florescence? It's breathtaking.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Hold on tight.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Close call.

Speaker: sarah
Dialogue: Have you been drinking?

Speaker: minnie
Dialogue: Kelly? Bart's not here, he -

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Oh, that's all right. Actually, I'm here to see Tabby. Just to do a little painting with her.

Speaker: minnie
Dialogue: She's out back in her studio.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Thanks.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: Kelly?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Hey. I warned you I'd come.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: You did.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Maybe I should go --

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: Well you're here now. Go ahead. Set your canvas up. Use one of the ones in the corner.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: Brushes are in the jar. Paint's in the drawer.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: I brought my own.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: Well then.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Does it mess up your concentration? Me being here?

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Oh. That's good.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: Just don't talk.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Why would I?

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: I'm kidding.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Right. Irony. I like that.

Speaker: miner
Dialogue: Hey! Hey babe.

Speaker: miner
Dialogue: Miner Webber.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Webber Miner.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: Kelly. This is Kelly -

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Kelly Ernswiler. Sorry. I -

Speaker: miner
Dialogue: Quite all right.  So, what do we have here, a little painting class?

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: Kelly's a friend of Bart's. He paints.

Speaker: miner
Dialogue: Oh? What's your real job?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: That would be stock boy at the Shop Rite. But, as President Don Kaminsky says, every employee is part owner. So you could say I'm a captain-of- industry in training. Kind of capitalist larva.

Speaker: miner
Dialogue: That's quite an image.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Only if you see the most magical part. Do you see?

Speaker: miner
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: One day I'll be a beautiful butterfly. First I'll have to be a pupa though. I figure I won't be going out much then. Pupa: the awkward adolescence of the insect world.

Speaker: miner
Dialogue: Whatever it takes to get you through the day.

Speaker: miner
Dialogue: I have the afternoon off. Come away with me.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: I'm not at a good stopping point.

Speaker: miner
Dialogue: Oh, come on. They'll still be here.  I know you'll still be here.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: I really shouldn't.

Speaker: miner
Dialogue: But everyone will be coming soon. And it will get all crazy, and we won't have any time to ourselves.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: We will. I promise.

Speaker: miner
Dialogue: Like tonight? We can practice honeymoon suite.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: Maybe. Probably.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Is he always like that?

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: Like what?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Overbearing.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: Just because he didn't want to picture you as a pupa?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Oh, he will - later. When he's alone. Whether he wants to or not.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Not that though. How he wanted you to stop.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: He wants to be with me. What's so bad about that?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Just because some one wants to be with you doesn't mean they're good for you.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: No one should ever ask you to stop. If you stop, you might not be able to start again. Or you might start again, only things will be different.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: Well, that's sweet -

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: It's not sweet, actually. It's just the truth.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: Hey, I can take care of myself.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: When's the wedding?

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: At the end of the month. But don't ask me about it. It makes me nervous.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Why? Is something wrong?

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: What are you painting?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Really, there are so many layers of - imagistic symbolism - that I really don't feel comfortable summing it up, but, well - it's a recurring dream image. A mermaid riding a rocket ship.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: How?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: What do you mean, "how?" Sidesaddle. She's riding it sidesaddle. She's got a fish tail, for chrissake. I haven't decided yet if she's got scuba gear on or not.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: Do you have any idea what you're talking about?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Does that matter?

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: Well, some people actually say what they really think.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: What if they don't know what they really think?

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: It doesn't matter. It's called being yourself.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Sounds boring.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: Not boring. Scary and wonderful and exciting.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Hey. I'm trying to create here. Stop distracting me.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Mom's got you working late?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Wow. You're really good. Why do you make those stupid animals for mom?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: I'm making a lot of art these days. I guess that means a lot of lessons.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Oh, that's all?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Hey you two. I'll try not to act surprised. It might spoil the moment.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: I can't do this. I have to go.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Keller, I think I'm missing some art supplies. Have you seen them around the house?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: No, I haven't.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: I don't know what to do with him.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: When are you going to let me give you your own show? We could do it for real.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: -- But I told you I want to take German --

Speaker: harrison
Dialogue: German's a Cold War language. You can't get any kind of State Department position without more diverse linguistic training than that. You'll take Chinese.

Speaker: harrison
Dialogue: Are we on the same page?

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Same page.

Speaker: mathilda
Dialogue: So darling, when are you going to bite the bullet and do the seating arrangement?

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: I can't deal with that stuff, ma. I don't care who sits next to whom. I should have eloped.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: After all, Mrs. Bowland, sometimes when you bite the bullet, it explodes in your mouth.

Speaker: mathilda
Dialogue: Why, I've never thought about it before but that is a rather strange expression, isn't it? You wouldn't say, "Sooner or later you've got to put the grenade in your pants," would you?

Speaker: harrison
Dialogue: But have you ever noticed how in movies they always bite the grenade before they throw it?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Yeah, but they never take a bite out of their pants.

Speaker: mathilda
Dialogue: What an unusual conversation! Do you have similar discussions at the dinner table with your family, Kelly?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Basically. I ask why all the furniture is missing and my Dad reminisces about dropping acid and watching Neil Armstrong walk on the moon.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: He talks about art.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: My mother's kind of an artist, so -

Speaker: harrison
Dialogue: You come from a creative family, do you?

Speaker: mathilda
Dialogue: I wish my boys would talk to me about my passions. I can't get them anywhere near the subject of my garden.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: I noticed your magnolias. Very fine specimens.

Speaker: mathilda
Dialogue: They are fine, aren't they?

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Is there nothing you can't discuss?

Speaker: harrison
Dialogue: Here, Kelly, try a bit of these leeks. Minnie has a way with the white sauce.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: My dad has this friend who's a director. He's shooting a documentary for the History Channel.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Cool.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: He needs some guys to do a reenactment of some European theater battles for him.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: We're going to be on the History Channel?

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: I haven't asked you yet.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Oh, come on.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Well, if you want to. Next weekend. But you have to take it seriously.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: What do you mean? Of course I will.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: From what I've seen, you play fast and loose with your characterizations. This has got to be straight up.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: I'm not "fast and loose." I play the emotional truth. I make it real.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Like back in the dining room?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: What does that have to do with it?

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: "I noticed your magnolias. Very fine specimens." That was real?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: What is this about?

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: You just seem to have your own agenda, that's all.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: My own agenda? What other reason is there to do anything?

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: I'm just saying. I know the difference between fantasy and reality.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Are you saying I don't?

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Why didn't you tell me your dad was a burn-out?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Why do you steal from yours?

Dialogue: Kelly! I told some of your teachers about your presentation. We're all really looking forward to it.

Speaker: sarah
Dialogue: What presentation?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: I don't want to talk about it. As a matter of fact, do me a favor and pretend you never heard anything about it.

Speaker: sarah
Dialogue: Okay. Um.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: What, Sarah?

Speaker: sarah
Dialogue: It's nothing. I -

Speaker: sarah
Dialogue: I have an extra ticket to Aerosmith this weekend.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Aw Sarah, that's really great, I mean. It's just that - I'm busy.

Speaker: sarah
Dialogue: Oh. Yeah, I figured. Okay. I'll see you in the dairy section, though.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Right.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: What are you doing here?

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: I tracked you down. There's someone I'd like you to meet.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Are you one too?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Yup.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: And what do you see in that?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Living, dying, camaraderie, bravery - the big stuff. Things we don't have anymore.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: I see.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: And do you think it's brave getting trench foot and syphilis, eating another ration of spoiled frank and beans out of a dented can?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Well, no -

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Yeah, that wouldn't be much fun, would it?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: No, sir.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Parts of it were kind of fun though. I got separated from my platoon and lived for two weeks in the forest of the Ardennes living off what I could kill.  I felt very close to the land.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: I met him when my mom made me go around caroling with the Youth Group.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: You don't really believe that stuff about Berlin? And Hitler's compound?

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Does it matter?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Of course it matters. Doesn't the truth matter?

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: I don't know. You tell me.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: I want a drink. Let me borrow a couple bucks.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: I told you not to play him for money.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: I was trying to be nice. He's your friend.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Exactly. You should know better. What do you want.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Mountain Dew -

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: -- Oh shit.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Kelly!

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: That woman's calling you.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Bart. Meet my mom.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: What a nice surprise. It's so nice to finally meet you.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Likewise. So, doing a little business?

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: A little is right. But I work it as much as I can.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: So, what have you boys been up to?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Bart took me to meet his friend Charlie at the Old Soldiers' Home.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Charlie at the Old Soldiers' Home?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: You don't know him.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: You boys should swing by Care House. There are some Vets there.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: We can't.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: Oh. Well - okay.

Speaker: eve
Dialogue: I should go. But you boys should come over to our house some time.  I know your family must get tired of him.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Not at all. But I'd love to, anyway.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: There you go. Now you know everything.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: What's your problem? She's pretty cute.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Don't you want your soda?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Forget it.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: So filming's on Saturday. Can you make it?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Are you kidding?

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Good. It's gonna be really cool. He's got an explosives expert coming.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: What's up?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Remember that stupid speech?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: I'm supposed to give it next week.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Maybe you should talk to my dad about it.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: You think he'd go for that?

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Of course. He loves you. He was talking the other day about helping you out.  Want to go to Dartmouth?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Are you serious?

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: He was. If you applied for Spring Semester, he could "pull some strings."

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: I don't think that would work for me. Considering -- my background.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Yeah, probably not.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: I'm not properly socialized. I wouldn't fit in.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: That's bullshit.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: No, it's not.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Tell that to my family. They're like your fucking fan club.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Even Tabby likes you.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: So much she ratted me out to you.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Well, she's inviting you to the wedding.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Oh.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: But you probably won't enjoy that much, will you?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: I don't know what you're talking about. Weddings? I love weddings. I always get drunk and make out with someone's cousin.

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: Good, I'll call mom's nephew Fletcher and tell him to expect a little action.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Fletcher, eh?

Speaker: bart
Dialogue: He's twelve. Let me give some advice. He's very into sharks at the moment.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Why did you tell --

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: What? Oh, I'm sorry.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: Miner and I broke up.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: I'm sorry.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Honestly? I didn't think you two were right for each other.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: You did, huh?

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: Like this painting. Stare at it too long and you can't see it anymore. But if someone else sees it for the first time, they can tell exactly what it is.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: I don't need any more bullshit right now.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: He could never understand you.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: I'm not as complicated as you think.

Speaker: kelly
Dialogue: I never said you were complicated.

Speaker: tabby
Dialogue: Oh.

Speaker: kelly
